pullRequest.title: Add withMap to MutableMap
pullRequest.bodyText:
Signed-off-by: Mohammed Aboullaite aboullaite.mohammed@gmail.com
This PR adds withMap a requested in #761

nodes.bodyText: Please revert this file
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,16 @@
+<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>

nodes.bodyText:
Can you add a test case for empty maps?

Input map is empty, target map is non-empty
Input map is empty, target map is empty
Input map is non-empty, target map is empty

nodes.bodyText: additional keys and values (it should be plural)
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -152,6 +152,25 @@ default boolean removeIf(Predicate2<? super K, ? super V> predicate)
      */
     MutableMapIterable<K, V> withKeyValue(K key, V value);
 
+    /**
+     * This method allows mutable, fixed size, and immutable maps the ability to add elements of a Map to their existing
+     * elements. In order to support fixed size maps, a new instance of a map would have to be returned including the
+     * keys and values of the original plus the additional key and value. In the case of mutable maps, the original map

nodes.bodyText: are we supporting this on fixed size and immutable maps?
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -152,6 +152,25 @@ default boolean removeIf(Predicate2<? super K, ? super V> predicate)
      */
     MutableMapIterable<K, V> withKeyValue(K key, V value);
 
+    /**
+     * This method allows mutable, fixed size, and immutable maps the ability to add elements of a Map to their existing

nodes.bodyText: Please add since 10.3.0
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -152,6 +152,25 @@ default boolean removeIf(Predicate2 predicate) */ MutableMapIterable withKeyValue(K key, V value); + /** + * This method allows mutable, fixed size, and immutable maps the ability to add elements of a Map to their existing + * elements. In order to support fixed size maps, a new instance of a map would have to be returned including the + * keys and values of the original plus the additional key and value. In the case of mutable maps, the original map + * is modified and then returned. In order to use this method properly with mutable and fixed size maps the + * following approach must be taken: + *

+ * 

+     * map = map.withKeyValue("new key", "new value");
+     *
+ * In the case of FixedSizeMap, a new instance will be returned by withKeyValue, and any variables that + * previously referenced the original map will need to be redirected to reference the new instance. In the case + * of a FastMap or UnifiedMap, you will be replacing the reference to map with map, since FastMap and UnifiedMap + * will both return "this" after calling put on themselves. + * + * @see #put(Object, Object) + */ + MutableMapIterable withMap(Map map);

nodes.bodyText: @donraab suggests to have a since tag on each interface.
thank you for fixing this!

You can simplify this test to:
Verify.assertThrows(UnsupportedOperationException.class, () -> this.newMapWithKeyValue(1, 'a').withMap(Maps.mutable.with(1, Character.valueOf("a"))));
Maps.mutable.empty()
refer to above.
Maps.mutable.empty()
This can be simplified to Maps.mutable.with("B", 22, "C", 3)
Maps.mutable.empty()
Sample as above
Maps.mutable.empty()
Please revert this. It causes confusion while reviewing git history.
Suggested change

"with mutable maps"
I feel like this must mean "immutable" no?
Does the method return this? It should say so.
This behaves kind of like putAll() right? The link in @see should be to putAll if so.
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -152,6 +152,25 @@ default boolean removeIf(Predicate2 predicate) */ MutableMapIterable withKeyValue(K key, V value); + /** + * This method allows mutable, fixed size, and immutable maps the ability to add elements of a Map to their existing + * elements. In order to support fixed size maps, a new instance of a map would have to be returned including the + * keys and values of the original plus the additional key and value. In the case of mutable maps, the original map + * is modified and then returned. In order to use this method properly with mutable and fixed size maps the + * following approach must be taken: + *

+ * 

+     * map = map.withKeyValue("new key", "new value");
+     *
+ * In the case of FixedSizeMap, a new instance will be returned by withKeyValue, and any variables that + * previously referenced the original map will need to be redirected to reference the new instance. In the case + * of a FastMap or UnifiedMap, you will be replacing the reference to map with map, since FastMap and UnifiedMap + * will both return "this" after calling put on themselves. + * + * @see #put(Object, Object) + */ + MutableMapIterable withMap(Map map);

nodes.bodyText: Synchronized wrappers should delegate to methods of the same name. But then return this, the wrapper.
While I do think we should pull the method up, we need it to have the correct generics, which is a breaking change. It needs the bounded wildcards ? extends K, ? extends V
nodes.diffHunk: @@ -161,11 +161,15 @@ default boolean removeIf(Predicate2 predicate) * map = map.withMap(someMap); * * - * @see #put(Object, Object) + * @see #putAll(Map) * * @since 10.3.0 */ - MutableMapIterable withMap(Map map); + default MutableMapIterable withMap(Map map)

nodes.bodyText: this could be this.putAll instead of this.getDelegate().putAll but I'm not sure if that matters
Any reason not to do this.putAll(); return this; ?

nodes.bodyText:
The javadoc seems wrong. At first I thought this was going to be about a method on mutable/immutable maps. If you're not sure if the method is mutating or not, then the safe thing to do is:
newReference = oldReference.possiblyMutatingMethod(args)

This one is specifically on mutable maps so the guidance doesn't need to be, and should not be followed. If you just delete "In order to use this method properly" until the end, I think it's good.
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -152,6 +152,25 @@ default boolean removeIf(Predicate2 predicate) */ MutableMapIterable withKeyValue(K key, V value); + /** + * This method allows mutable maps the ability to add elements of a Map to their existing + * elements. The original map is modified and then returned. In order to use this method properly with mutable maps + * the following approach must be taken: + *

+ * 

+     * map = map.withMap(someMap);
+     *

nodes.bodyText: Some of the synchronized wrappers call this.putAll and some call this.getDelegate.putAll. I prefer this.putAll, like we see here.
